newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Hyundai Motor to cut production hours.
newsitem.headline: Hyundai Motor to cut production hours.

text.p: South Korea's largest carmaker Hyundai Motor Co will reduce vehicle production by four hours a day from April 8 to 12, a company spokesman said on Thursday.
"Line workers will not work overtime for five days as we need to realign assembly lines to produce more Tiburones and Avantes, which are major export models," the spokesman said.
The company earlier said it was considering cutting production because of rising inventory.
"The decision will also help reduce our inventory," the spokesman added. Hyundai's inventories totalled about 50,000 vehicles at end-March. No comparative figures were given.
Hyundai Motor currently runs assembly lines for 20 hours a day, including four hours of overtime work.
Hyundai's vehicle sales in March fell 7.6 percent to 101,957 units from 110,329 a year earlier. Demestic vehicle sales fell 16.2 percent to 50,383 in the month.
The reduction in work hours would cut inventories by 3,100 units, the spokesman said.

A Korea Automobile Manufacturers' Association official said vehicle inventories by South Korean carmakers hit a high last month, far outpacing previous record of 100,000 units. No exact figure was given.
Two other major South Korean carmakers -- Kia Motors Corp and Daewoo Motor Co -- said they had no plan to reduce working hours.
